abstract.p: Nokkvi Eliasson, photographer from Reykjavik, Iceland, has dozens of black-and-white images of abandoned farmhouses on his Web site; photo (S)

block.p: Nokkvi Eliasson, a photographer from Reykjavik, Iceland, has dozens of black-and-white images of abandoned farmhouses on his Web site, most of them with Iceland's big sky looming in the background (www.islandia .is/nokkvi/page1.htm).
There are also photographs of people, animals and landscapes.

Nokkvi Eliasson, a photographer from Reykjavik, Iceland, has dozens of black-and-white images of abandoned farmhouses on his Web site, most of them with Iceland's big sky looming in the background (www.islandia .is/nokkvi/page1.htm).
There are also photographs of people, animals and landscapes.
''Until about 15 years ago, farming was good business,'' Mr. Eliasson said. ''Now, people are moving to the towns and leaving the farms behind.''

roadless.fs.fed.us/ A site from the U. S. Forest Service about conservation plans for roadless areas of national forests, including the Tongass National Forest in Alaska, with maps, land surveys and profiles and pictures of a dozen of the forests.
